Actually, the Rubiks Cube sort of has less configurations. There are these things called orbits in a Rubiks Cube, where you can only go to a group of specific combination on the cube. If you flip an edge, you can never get it back to its solved position, because it is in a different orbit. There are 12 orbits, so the amount of different combinations on a Rubiks Cube is actually (excluding the 11 orbits different from the main orbit which contains the solved position) 3,604,333,606,207,488,000, which is still big.

the Rubix cube possible combinations is closer to only 80 million. there are 26 cubes, but corners can only be on a corner, edge only on edge etc. so you have 8 factorial, plus 12 factorial, plus 6 factorial. And then some of those are just inversions of each other: divide by 6. =  79,840,440 total

When a tree falls in the forest, it makes no sound unless someone hears it. Without a brain, sound does not exist. A falling tree merely makes molecules of air vibrate, compressing them and rarefying them into waves of changing air pressure. In humans and animals, the auditory task is to convert the physical properties of sound-wave energy into electrochemical neural activity that travels to the brain, which we then perceive as sound. The waves themselves make no sounds.

This was actually a fun calculation. Let's assume that a person burns 1800 Cal/day for his/her entire lifetime of 75 yrs. Let us also assume that all of these calories come from glucose (easier to calculate). Using the standard stoichiometric formula for cellular respiration, 450 g of sugar (4Cal/g) react with 480 g of O2 daily. In the entire lifetime, 13,149 kg of O2 are used. At sea level and 20 C, this takes up 9,884,715 L. Since O2 is just 21 % of air, a person breathes a lot more than that.

I know for a fact. It's great for explaining Group mathematics. The calculation of how many positions the cube can be in is a great teaching tool, but most of the positions they count you can't get to without taking the cube apart.
